jukugo.d: One of many many Japanese words for 'normal.' The nuance of いっぱんてき　is ordinary, non-special - as opposed to a member of a special group of people of things. 一般的な人 means, an average person. As in, 'an average person is not allowed in this Yakuza bar.'
the best! Number one!
hangover (literally: 'paying for your drink'）
PREFIX meaning double, as in ""double-chin"" or ""twin-engine plane.""
to finish work on a project - an annual report, a re-formatting of the database, etc.
roger that!  ('I got it!') (originally used by military, but now often used when you text, because of its brevity)!
to expire, to come to an end (used about contracts or subscriptions expiring)
parents and child together - also the rather cruel name for a traditional dish: boiled chicken served with scrambled eggs.

the condition something's in. Can be used with a living thing or object. Always used only with いい or 悪い. Usually emphaizes the LONG TERM condition. Although hungover people have been heard to remark, 調子が悪い！
her. Might also mean 'girlfriend' depending on context.
the polite- but not formal - way to say woman
girl . Newspapers use it for a female up through junior high, but guys talking about 'chicks,dude' might use it to refer to a 20 year old.
young girl - usually 5- 15 years old.
female - emphasizes biology, (sex, rather than gender).

PREFIX used about women from first grade through college. Used to refer to female students as a group: ""女子 line up on the left side of the class, 男子 (danshi) line up on the right side."" BOOBOO: You wouldn't say ""She's a joshi.""
literally, 'look' or 'shape,' as in 'He's dressed as a woman' : おんなの格好してる。
curiosity
entrance (often shortened to 入口）
pester someone, usually for sex
the kind of depressing place where you get a ticket or food from a person in a box with usually a bulletproof plexiglas window between you and them.
a pretext. Like, ""I'm studying to be a preacher, but that's just a pretext for me to meet virgin dudes.""
crude. Like chicks sitting with their legs open or guys picking their nose.
brand new shit - just on the market
can be used of people or things. It means graceful or sophisticated in a quiet or understated way. When it comes to people, 上品 is usually used about women, I mean 'ladies.'

ANY word - unlike the related term 単語（たんご）、　言葉 can refer to compound words, or onomonopoeia. Also 言葉 can mean ""way of speaking."" There are expressions like ""watch what you say!"" that use 言葉 this way: 言葉使い が丁寧 (her way of speaking is very polite!) or 言葉大切につかいましょう （let's be careful how we speak!)
we say ""He speaks broken English"".Japanese say, ""He speaks katakoto nihongo.""
XXX is untalented, poorly performed, or poorly made.

a mystery or unexplainable thing. BOOBOO:NOT a mystery like Sherlock Holmes or ""Colonel Mustard, in the drawing room, with the double-headed dildo."" A mystery like how fat Americans are, or why Sting is famous. That's a fushigi.

To not have enough of a physical thing (money, time, nurses, teachers.) Also implies that there is a specific amount that is required, For example -犬不足 (a dog shortage). There's no particle or verb needed.
an affair - cheating
a negative sentence. 'He doesn't , we don't, I can not,' are examples of English negatives. ひていけい is a good word to know if you want to ask your friends, 'How do you use this word in the negative?'

jukugo.m: a formal word for 'to deny' (the politician denied the allegations)

jukugo.d: absolute refusal- unlike 拒む (こばむ）,　拒否 is always verbal - an exit line. Like if you tell a guy 'no thanks' 10 times and he won't go away, you use 拒否. As in, '私がきょひした。’

jukugo.m: the tenth day of the month

jukugo.d: about that little ""ヶ"" thing - it's pronounced KA, and means ""number of months' time"". If you take it out, you'd be left with  ""十月"", meaning October.

twenty years old - traditionally the age at which Japanese turn into adults and get presents, kimono, etc. So, naturally it has its own special pronunciation that doesn't make any sense, since it SHOULD be called にじゅうさい。 Whatever. Tradition.
used XXX (books, cars, your dad's condoms)
used clothes - a used clothes store is a 古着屋（ふるぎや）
classical, like Shakespeare or Bach or Shunga something.

Pretty close to 予定　（よてい） in meaning, but perhaps more elaborate - you'd use 計画 to say ""I have a plan to get rich!"" or to say ""I planned out our whole vacation to 3 countries."" . . but you wouldn't use 予定。
excessive, uncalled-for, and unnecessary (usually used in the context of 余計なお世話だよ！　（よけいなおせわだよ！）: 'Mind your own business!')

jukugo.m: the seventh day of the month

jukugo.d: comparatively (BOOBOO: you DON'T use a 'na' at the end, for some reason)
a more formal word for 'compare': You'd 比べる AC/DC albums to see which one rocked the most, but you'd 比較 the GDP of developing nations.
Day of the week (BOOBOO； in practice, most Japanese omit the final '日'.So, 木曜日(もくようび） becomes simply 木曜 (もくよう）)
add 日, (which is short for 日本), to 米, (which somehow means ""America""), and you have a word which means ""East-and-West"" or ""East meets West."" Usually seen on cultural exchange-related things.
insect, (a more scientific term than 'むし')
physical speed or agility, but without any advanced kung-fu techniques. A fast bird or lizard. Doing a simple task at the office, but very speedily.
the more informal, spoken word for husband (your own or other peoples') - (BOOBOO: if you're talking about someone else's man, say お旦那さん (more polite!))

jukugo.m: once you've started to do xxx . . .
jukugo.d: once you've started to do xxx . . . (i.e. once you've gotten married, you can't get divorced! once you've promised, you can't go back on it!)

interesting, (in a good way) but also can mean funny (as in, laughing at you!) this deliberate ambiguity being a big thing with Japanese Sarcasm. Although in this case, fully half the time people are being serious.
white people (do the Humpty Hump, they do the humpty hump)
a more formal way to say ""everyone.""

jukugo.m: hostess clubs, host clubs,strip clubs, etc.

jukugo.d: flood (be careful - the す is pronounced ず、which is really unusual.)
a drop of water
big ditch. who cares.
hot spring baths (although most onsen use artificially heated water from regular wells these days)
the poetic 'forever'： I'll hate you forever! We shall rule the world forever!
forever - the science word. (BOOBOO : the poetic word is 'eien'.(永遠))
a COUNTER for the number of nights you stay. You use this when making a reservation at a hotel. Ippaku is , of course, one night.

jukugo.m: to stay somewhere for two nights.

jukugo.d: the act of staying the night -(kind of formal; you might read it in a hotel guidebook, but you wouldn't say ""Let's 宿泊 over there, guys!""
What you are experiencing right now while studying Japanese!
three months' time, three months' duration
the New Year - (BOOBOO: in Japan, that means not just January first but the whole first week)
Explanation / to explain
unknown, unclear. (the body's identity remains unknown / an unknown tribe made these carvings of your mama's ass)

jukugo.k: 明けましておめでとう
jukugo.r: あけまして おめでとう!
jukugo.d: Happy new year! (only noobs say this before Jan 1st. In the last part of December, we say, ""良いお年を!"" (よいおとしを!)
grease or fat (refers to both the kind used in cooking, AND the kind that makes your mama's neighbors take out earthquake insurance )
daring or bold, - not just courageous, but taking risks when you don't need to. Not just a bank-robbery, but a bank robbery at high noon, while wearing Hirohito masks!.
rising sun. As in, 'land of the. . .' Also as in Asahi beer.
A fire - not like the fire in your stepdad's crackpipe; like the fire that spreads from his crackpipe and engulfs your whole trailer.
inflammation, swelling
a joke - you'll often hear: ""冗談じゃない！” ('I'm not kidding!')
a consultation - it doesn't have to be formal. If you want to see your teacher after class, that's a soudan.
a COUNTER for - roughly, 'city block.' 3丁目, 4丁目, etc. You need to know this if you ever want to read an address.
exactly, precisely. Just right.
manners used in everyday situations. Just good common sense.

jukugo.m: lamp -(BOOBOO: in practice, everyone just says でんき)

jukugo.d: a traditional monster, one you'll still see all the time in illustrations or storefronts. They used to be crazy vicious, jumping up out of the lake and eating your intestines while you're still alive, but now they're more like cute, mischievous mascots -
to correct or revise some written thing - lyrics, a report, an article, or even (god forbid) a Kanji book.
the countryside,hicksville
check into the hospital - not for a simple exam, but like you have to stay there at least one night, you're too sick to leave.

jukugo.m: to start school at a new school

jukugo.d: SUFFIX meaning 'person from XXX country.' AmerikaJIN, FranceJIN, etc.
famous - usually used like this: 人気　が　ある！
Life, as in someone's entire life, or life in general:. ""He lived a quiet life."" ""Life is a bitch."" ""Life span.""
adult, as opposed to minor, not as opposed to 'with clothes on.'
someone who out-ranks you - at work, school, or in society.
geometry (I like this because it seems that even the Chinese sages who made up this word were confused by geometry. It's like 'the science of what the fuck??')
signal, i.e. traffic signal
the mechanization of a society or of an industry.
cherry-blossom looking-at-and-getting-bombed parties
this has 2 meanings. One is ""I'm not good at this"" and the second is ""I don't like this""  Clever Japanese!

usually defined as 'confidential,' but that makes it sound more serious than it is - like a spy document or something. Actually, 内緒 is kind of a kids' word. ""Keep this information between us two.""

sarcasm OR irony. Japanese DO have a sense of sarcasm,(for example, calling the traditional chicken-and-scrambled-eggs dish ""parents and child"") but it is so different than the Western say-the-opposite-of-what-you-mean style that Japanese don't have a word for western sarc. So they seem to have taken their word for Irony and pressed it into service for sarcasm as well.

jukugo.m: to stand out in a crowd.

jukugo.d: this is a term used in counting things in a row. For instance, in English we'd say ""Second book from the right"" or ""Third shelf from the top"" in Japanese, they'd say: 2番目のbook OR 4番目のshelf.
this has so many meanings: useless, bad, 'stop!' or just 'no way!'
one's own (dog, blunt, fungus, etc.) - BOOBOO: sometimes it also is used to mean ""you"" or ""she"", as in ""She did it herself,  as opposed to having others do it for her.""

SUFFIX, meaning 'name of restaurant' . So you can tell ""Joe's亭"" (Joe's diner)　apart from ""Joe's本屋""　（Joe's bookstore)
suspension or stoppage (i.e. they cut my electricity because I didn't pay the bill). This is usually used in official announcements or bills. You wouldn't say to your friend, ""I 停止-ed watching TV.""
sure this is a scary and long word, but if you live here, you'll use it everyday： It means ""local train"" (literally, ""stopping at each station train"")
SUFFIX meaning, 'way to do.' for instance,  ギターを弾く； means 'to play the guitar.' so,ギターの弾き方； means 'the way to play the guitar.'
Most often used in the negative: 'Shikata ga nai.' as in, 'fuck it.'
one-sided, one-way. Often used in the phrase : xxx 一方だ！ (meaning, more and more xxx - i.e. ""more and more hot"", ""more and more popular,"" etc.)
just in case (literally, 'on the one-in-10,000 chance that something goes wrong')
Fuckin' banzai, man!!!! (literally '10,000 years', meaning, 'May the Emperor live 10,000 years!' is what you shout as you charge into battle)
same as たずねる,(訪ねる）, but it's a noun.

""Those dudes."" One of the only plurals in Japanese!
a letter- whether kana, kanji, or alphabet.

to order an item - both in a store and by mail. Also, if you ask your friend to do an annoying and detailed favor, like, ""Could you do the laundry again with this other kind of soap!"", that's chuumon.

the downfall of a civilization or the dying-out of a certain ethnic group. But it doesn't have 'downfall's moral judgement.

has two meanings: If you say it about yourself, it means you feel terrible. If you say it about someone/thing else, it means,""That's gross and pathetic.""

Example phrase:要点だけ話して！　(""Get to the point!"")

politics. (FR：literally ""administer and cure"",which is a bit of a laugh)
healing in general : (the healing process / an unhealed wound / taking too long to heal)

an attitude/manner (defiant, peaceful, etc.) or stance (anti-trade, pro-shinto, anti-corporate). When it comes to the first meaning, 態度 is something you can tell just by looking at the person - they might not be doing it intentionally.

the state or status of something: water is the liquid state of h20, but ice is the solid state. State of shock. Pristine state. Also can mean the state of affairs : good, bad, deadlocked, deteroriorating, improving.

Showa Era： (In Japan, a new　時代 (era) begins every time a new Emperor is crowned, and lasts until the next one is crowned. The Japanese - like Pol Pot - start counting from Year One every time they enter a new era.
one minute of time. (2 minutes = 二分（にふん）、　3 minutes = 三分(三分), etc.)

Whereas, 忍耐 has more a passive nuance - ""Continue doing nothing, fight the urge to counter-attack or snap back.""

more formal than　脅す 　. Not just to threaten, but to be intimidating.

Tokyo -to. Tokyo is the capital of Japan, so　it has ""-to"" on the end of it. Most cities have a 市（し） instead. And most prefectures have  a 県 (けん） instead. If you think that's confusing, look at Washington DC - it's not a state, but it's not a city. It's a ""district."" Huh?
background (both in the sense of the background of a photo, and the background context of a story)
A nice view - of nature or even the big crosswalk at Shibuya.
an exhibition or trade-show (International Plumbing Equipment Expo 2010!)
instructions　ー not like instructions from your boss, but like the instruction manual you get with your new vacuum cleaner.

criterion - the basis for judging a sex partner, potential job applicant, which songs to buy, etc.  Also - unlike the OTHER きじゅん （規準）、THIS きじゅん ALSO has a second meaning:  'standard', as in, standard wages,  standard price, the gold standard, standard medical ethics. Metric is our standard of measurement in Japan, whereas in USA they use their own standard.

jukugo.d: Treatment - but unlike 扱う, 取り扱う is ONLY used for objects or cases. i.e. The police are handling the racial hate-crime very carefully.
a crackdown, a regulation of something that was unregulated

the lowest - both in the moral sense of ""He's the lowest kind of sexual predator"" and in the mathematical sense of ""Crime rates are the lowest in 30 years,"" or ""Do this for a minimum of 5 minutes per day.""
take a sneak picture, usually of a woman dropping a deuce in a public restroom. Also known as 'ninjashotting.'

to embarrass one's self. (You can't say this about yourself, in the manner of, ""OH! I fucked up!"" But you can say はじをかいた! to someone else, like a mother scolding a child who doesn't know it's impolite to yell ""POOOPY POOOPY!"")
shameless (literally, ""Not knowing the meaning of shame"")

jukugo.m: something which someone has taken the trouble to do
jukugo.d: something which someone has taken the trouble to do for you. Like a 折角 rhubarb pie that you have to eat even though you are allergic to fucking rhubarb.
break a bone- fracture.
philosophy (adj.: 哲学的な、てつがくてきな）
a bamboo shoot, also a famous harajuku fashion shop
simple or easy, but in a good way
any strategy for succeeding － in war, business, school, etc.
last month, last year, etc.
to get close to, to approach.(usually used in the negative, on warning signs: danger! keep out! danger! high voltage! 近寄るな!)

in this neighborhood, around here- (BOOBOO: 近所 is strictly relative to where you are standing at the time. You can't say 'Shibuya is a neighborhood in tokyo,' - in that case, you have to use MACHI(町)。)
to draw close to a physical destination or a goal.
pressure (圧迫な ＝ overpowering)
persecution of a minority group (political word)
an application (for a loan or to go to college, etc)
a crowd of people- (BOOBOO : not necessarily all people doing the same thing(i.e. 'the crowd at the Sinatra show'). It means 'crowds in general,' as in, 'It gets crowded after 4 PM.' )
to deliver. Used about business - used when money changes hands. Deliver by truck or UPS or FEDEX.
SUFFIX, meaning ""more than one of XXX.""But unlike English, you can't pluralize just any word.
to describe, to give an in-depth account of. Generally means an entire chapter, if not a whole book.
forests in general. (forest ecology, forest creatures, forestry)

used for counting. Ippon is one book. Psyche! ISSATSU (一冊) is one book, ippon is one cylindrical object. Makes sense if you imagine that back when Chinese sages were inventing kanji, books were written on scrolls and shit。
one's real feelings, as opposed to 建前　（たてまえ）. You know, the 2 faces that only Japanese people have, as if no one else in the world would dream of being so false, and all that bullshit.

jukugo.m: the real thing, not a counterfeit.

jukugo.d: originally, essentially , primairlyー Emphasizes the historical roots. Originally the EPA was supposed to protect the environment, but nowadays it's protecting the polluters!
concrete, literal, in practice . .  as opposed to abstract, in theory

Good night! (BOOBOO: You don't say this when you leave your friend's dinner party or when you leave your date standing on the curb weeping outside the restaurant, you only say it when you live in the same house: it's more like ""sleep tight!"", I guess.)
A holiday - Christmas, Arbor Day, etc.
stimulate something - a chemical reaction, a clitoris, whatever.  (v) ;a stimulus (n)
you'll see this sign a lot. It means 'now hiring!'
to edit. (editor:編集者 (へんしゅうしゃ）)
a whole bookcase (BOOBOO:  'tana'　（棚） by itself means an individual shelf of a hondana)
A somewhat newspaper-ish word for Prime Minister (BOOBOO: actually, most people say 総理 instead)

Sumo. I've seen a bunch of of straight porn featuring 'sexy sumo wrestler girls,' but I've been unable to find a single gay sumo porn. Which either means, a) gay dudes think sumo are trolls, b) gay dudes have too much respect for the manliness of Sumo to do a x-rated parody, or c) gay dudes just jerk it to regular sumo on the tube for free.
imagine. (imaginative： そうぞうてきな)
an impression of something. (like 印象, but you'd never use 感想 to mean 'first impression')
to mentally associate XXX with YYY. Like your psychologist says, ""Let's play a word-association game.""
forbidden by law. Common examples: smoking outdoors, parking your bike here, opening this door, busking on the street, breathing on a grandpa.
do not cross this line, no entry.
fruit. You might see this on signs, but in conversation, most people say フルーツ。
section chief - or department manager.
The subject of today's lesson (in school); the task at hand (at work)
pastries, cupcakes, etc. - also called ""sweets"" in Japanese-English. (BOOBOO:Not candy bars.)
east side of Japan ー including Tokyo.
practice , as in guitar, tennis, or jerking off
training - more serious than 練習； more like for the army or kung fu

senrensareta - literally 'polished.' Like the 'after' version of Eliza Doolittle - rich but also well-mannered. Not like Paris Hilton.  I guess 'cosmopolitan sophisticate' is the best English equivalent. Also applies to hi-class things that have been made in a very skillful way.
Cheers! Let's drink!
politically or morally conservative.

a guarantor. This may not sound like a useful word to know, but if you ever come to Nippon, you'll need a Japanese guarantor. For pretty much everything- getting an apartment, a visa, etc. Usually it's your boss. So if you lose your job, your boss can kick you out of your house AND the country. It's a sort of share-cropper system!
control or operate - usually a machine, but can also be used about politicians controlling the people.
pollution OR contamination. (BOOBOO : If you want to say ""environmental pollution,"" you have to use 汚染、　not 公害。)
complicated; having multiple things that make it complex.
noise - like traffic, static, the classic STORMTROOPERS OF DEATH song 'What's that noise?!?!?' etc.
Japanese-style (food, clothing, houses. . .)
private railway - uses the second meaning of '私’ (private)
xxx-seconds of time
immigrant (only applies to people who became Japanese citizens and generally their families live here for generations)(i.e. not you)
profit (both literal and figurative)
an archaic, literary word meaning, ""melancholy, pathos, grief."" (used about a novel, song, movie, or tone of voice, but not about a person).
literary word for nostalgia (BOOBOO: most people just say 懐かしい　（なつかしい！）)
the conclusion of something - the last chapter of a book or the last scene of a movie.
future (未来時制　(未来じせい）＝the future tense)
attempted xxx (murder, suicide, kidnapping, etc.)
interest in something
Europe and USA - but unfortunately due to racism, Japanese often use 欧米 to mean the West in general, ignoring Africa, South and Latin America and even Canada.
diagnosis (診断する＝to diagnose)
an inheritor, an heir, heiress
to carry on (the family business / a tradition)
clay. (BOOBOO : but not the finished pottery, which is '陶器', or 'とうき')
adhesive- like tape, glue, or maybe even velcro?
the essence of something. Pure pleasure! Pure blood! Pure honor!
an atomic particle, as in 'particle physics.'
it's possible to do.(I can run, I can shit, but I can't run and shit at the same time.)
a specific person's future (i.e. the dumb interview question, ""What do you see yourself doing 10 years from now?"") Also sometimes used with Japan's future.
number which has been assigned to a thing, as in phone number or apartment number, or ZIP code number.
police box - a small shop in your neighborhood where police hang out and wait to help you or jail you.
to judge or examine something - anything from Charles Manson's trial to American Idol. Anything with a panel of judges. Also when the fire marshal or the IRS comes to do an Official Inspection.
this has 2 meanings, both used equally often:

vital, important.
Can also be used as a sort of goodbye - but only in cases where you're sort of worried about the person. Like if they're coming down with a cold, you'd say, ""お大事に！”　instead of ”またね！”
wife (used about my own wife as well as your wife) (literally,'back of the house person' - OH SNAAAAAP!!)
old person ('70s and up). This isn't rude per se, but if you want to dismiss or belittle what an old fart just said, this is the word you use.
annoying, a pain in the ass.
SUFFIX meaning 'XXX and therefore dumb.' 古臭い　（ふるくさい) is one example　（so out of fashion that it is stinking) , also '田舎くさい　（いなくさい）' - meaning like 'stoopid redneck.'
to get all excited and freak out. to get really worked up. Not in a bad way. Like when you wet your pants after seeing n'sync.
arms: unlike the related term 武器(ぶき）, 兵器 generally means things that are very modern and big: bazookas, missiles, rocket launchers, howitzers.

skillful, dexterous. Like a kung-fu fighter that can jump around and not get kicked, or a pianist who plays hella difficult pieces without any fucked notes. There is also an implication that the person can improvise!
suddenly! Like 急に, but you can also use 突然 if you're sending someone an unexpected mail, or making a last-minute plan.
means impact (car crash) but also a conflict (India and Pakistan are on a collision course) or mental conflict (his communism conflicts with his love for the sexy CIA agent).
central. Tokyo has a famous train line: 中央線、(the central line).
any reflected, moving image - including images on TV or a computer screen, a shadow play, etc.
hero of an adventure story or legend - (BOOBOO: it's different from  the word for 'main character' (主人公(しゅじんこう）） which can be used in any kind of story.

Since it literally means 'losing dog,' you'd think that was a transliteration of the English 'underdog,' But no, it simply means loser or schlemiel. Japan doesn't really have much respect for plucky underdogs who dare to try and rise above their status.
surrender - unlike the more casual 降参　（こうさん）, 降伏 is used when you, like, lose a war.
silence. (BOOBOO: not to be confused with 静か　（しずか）).　静か means a quiet place. 沈黙 is like a awkward hush that falls over the crowd when your mom's g-string fell off at the superbowl.
to silently do xxx.
absolutely! (usually used to emphasize the word after it. But sometimes, the word being emphasized is omitted because it's so obvious (to Japanese))
just, natural, deserved - although it's often used like 'That's obvious, isn't it?'
traditional Japanese drums - the kind that can be up to 15 feet wide. (BOOBOO: Rock and roll drums are just called ドラム.)
Usually 漢 means Chinese: it's used in a lot of obscure words ('Chinese dictionary,' 'Chinese herbal medicine,' 'Chinese classical literature,' etc.)

jukugo.m: to criticize someone for no reason, just to nag at them.

jukugo.d:
a hardship, big trouble. Not like ""Oh, If I fail this test, I'm going to be in big trouble!"" こんなん is more like an ongoing hardship, like your parents died when you were young and you had to put yourself through school while working 20 hours a week washing dishes.
Also often used in this phrase: 困難の時代 (troubled times)
amazement, slack-jawed wonder

a pattern which does not have pictures: fractals , mandala, plaid, zeebra skin. wood. do NOT use about representational patterns like flower-print or kids’ pajamas with horsies on them. 模様 also has a more formal meaning: ‘the details of an incident’ : You might hear a train/airport announcement which says ""We will explain the details of the delay"" ( 遅れるの模様。 )
a model (this is literal! Model, like a snap-tite model car or model train)

c.m: standard / the best way to do

jukugo.d: a model: Can be a person (a role model, a model sudent), or a thing (a model home, a model economy). (BOOBOO: Not model like a plastic model tank or gandam)
to be at a loss, to feel like WTF can I do??
most people in the West called the Shogun government ""feudalism"", but the shoguns themselves called it BAKUFU。
vague, obscure: unlike the related term 紛らわしい　（まぎらわしい）、漠然 isn't intentionally misleading - it has more the sense of a vague old memory you can't picture clearly even if you try.
origin or cause of something

favor. Unlike the very personal ""恩"", giving and receiving 恩恵 is a more businesslike form of gratitude: 恩恵を受ける means ""to recieve a favor."" A sort of I'll-scratch-your-back-if-you-scratch-mine practicality.
ｉｎｇｒａｔｅ (literally, 'unaware of gratitude.')
a germ (usually used as a kids' insult - an ""EWW you're gross!"" kind of word)
every time. Every single fucking time. Jesus! Get it together, man. Sometimes I don't know what goes on in your head.
last time (last time, this happened, last time we met). although in practice people tend to use the more irritating and ambiguous 'この 前.' (back then)
personal, single-serving (one-to-one session with a teacher, personal pizza)(BOOBOO: don't confuse this with private -  private is こじんてきな 個人的な)
one small, usually roundish, thing - orange, apple, ipod
the atmosphere of a place (usually figurative!)

c.m: standard / the best way to do

jukugo.d: the extent, range scope, or bounds (extent of the earthquake-damaged area, scope of the congressional inquiry, range of the birds' migrations).
perimeter, circumference
SUFFIX meaning ‘bowl of hot rice and sweet sauce with a painfully stingy amount of XXXX on top' (XXX is usually beef or pork)
beef bowl (beef over rice).
your mama's big hairy balls
China (think, 'the Middle Kingdom')
international. As in a certain House of Pancakes (also used to refer to a couple where one person is a foreigner: こくさいてきな カップル.)
the people, as in, ""The Republicans are the People's party!""
nationwide,national (as in a national contest)
reason (for doing something)

emperor of Japan - never used about other countries. (BOOBOO: you don't say 天皇さん！　And you don't use his proper name - Hirohito or Akihito, either. You say, 天皇陛下　（てんのう　へいか) which means His Majesty The Emperor.
If you want an easy-to-read book that really dishes all the dirt on the Emperor system, read YAMATO DYNASTY by Sterling Seagrave.
emperor - like China, not like Japan. (BOOBOO: Japan's emperor is 天皇:てんのう.)

A common-place, easily possible wish: ""I'd like an aisle seat."" ""I'd like to fly nonstop.""　希望 might be better translated as 'request': 'Customers wishing to request a child-seat for their infant please see the waiter.'
to aim too high, to be over-ambitious.
""ohhhh, now I see!"" (very similar to a hearty 分かった！！　（わかった）, but it also has the nuance of, understanding AND agreeing whole-heartedly)
the subject of the sentence. AKA the thing Japanese people never say.
SUFFIX meaning 'ism'. As in capitalism, communism, materialism, and a Japanese grindcore band called 'intestine baalism.'
contract (one of the most hated words in the Japanese language)

c.m: enjoy a drink and a smoke

jukugo.d:
a coffee-shop. These are really popular because Japanese don't invite people over to their homes very often - they meet at the coffee-shop. This is fairly polite example to point to when a Japanese asks you, ""Do foreigners really think we're a cold people?""
BOOBOO: most Japanese don't say きっさてん。 they just say 喫茶、(きっさ)。

c.m: enjoy a drink and a smoke

jukugo.d: the act of smoking. You'll see this on signs a lot, meaning 'this is the smoking section.'
pure, clean, undiluted. More often used figuratively - about morals and such. Or ＊ahem＊ ethnicity.
telephone pole. Although, since in Japan all the telephone poles double as light poles (街灯) AND are festooned with every other imaginable cable to boot, I have no idea which word people use!
a person or animal native to the area. Indigenous.
parking lot. Interestingly, there is no word for 'parking space,' in the sense of ""Keep a lookout for a good space!""

pollution. Has a more broad meaning than the related word 汚染（おせん）。 Not just dirty smoggy air, but also noise pollution, the annoyance of someone talking on a cellphone on a train, and 情報公害　（じょうほうこうがい）: ""ad pollution"" - the inescapable advertisements one sees everywhere. BOOBOO:If you want to say ""environmental pollution,"" you have to use 汚染、　not 公害。
damage (to property) or casualties (human): used about earthquakes, wars, and crimes.

role, but more general and figurative than just 役（やく）。 Gay dudes who are top or bottom - that's 役割。 If your role is 'the black sheep of the family,"" that's 役割。 The guy in the boy-band who is ""the edgy one."" The person on the reality -tv show who is ""the crazy one.""
the best! Usually used about art or theatrical performances.
raw material - both literally and figuratively (as in, the raw data that you base your essay or report or novel on) (""I'm working on materal for my novel!"")
oxygen - which is kind of a Fucked Roots if you think about it - ""sour element?"" What have they got against oxygen?!? What SHOULD we be breathing?

jukugo.r: に さんか たんそ

jukugo.d: a blue traffic light - in English we call it a ""green traffic light."" (BOOBOO: In Japan, they call the same blue-greenish color '青い' - so it isn't exactly the English ""Green.""

jukugo.m: in the prime of one's life.

jukugo.d: Usually used in business. On-demand service. A bill for services.   When used with に、 it means, ""According to the customer's request,"" or ""According to her wishes.""
spirit- both in the sense of psychology and in the sense of religion. If you want to say ""Samurai spirits!"" this is the one you'll use.
circumstances. A euphemism for 'bad situation': crushing debt, mother is a prostitute, etc, in trouble with the mob, etc.

jukugo.m: affection : more than friendship and less than love.

jukugo.d: facial expression - although most people say ""XXXの顔をした”　（ｘｘｘのかおをした）, meaning ""She made an xxx-face.""
this is hard. It got tons of meanings: nama tv is live, not prerecorded. Nama beer is poured straight from the bottle, not like a fancy mixed drink. Nama information is first hand. Nama meat is raw.
living, moving thing . . . (BOOBOO：it doesn't apply to plants! Only little dudes that can move around and forage for food are いきもの)
SUFFIX which turns an adjective into a noun: possible+性=possibility. creative+性=creativity. 男性　＝ man, but 男性性＝ masculinity.
what you got from your pops.
one's full name -  first and last names.
a corporation - you'll usually see this word after the company name on their front window. DAMAGE, INC. = DAMAGE,株式会社; 　MURDER, INCORPORATED = MURDER株式会社。
This is the word used in financial terms about stocks IN GENERAL - IPO or 'go public' or 'stock amoritization' and the like
symmetrical (非対称的な　（ひたいしょうてきな = assymetrical!)
a  girl. Unlike the related term 少女,　乙女 emphasizes the ""pure, virginal"" aspect of  girlhood - used about girls around 12-19 years old.
to become dry or arid (weather or place) ; to dry out or desiccate.

jukugo.r: かあああああさあああん！

jukugo.d: regular ,intentional poison- as opposed to toxic pollutants or drugs.

the coast OR the beach! Unlike 浜辺 or 浜, 海岸 has a scientific meaning: the coastline, (regardless of if there's sand or not). You'll see 海岸 on maps or geography books. The useage of 海岸 is odd, even for Japanese. Where Americans will just say, ""Let's go to the beach!"", Japanese might suggest to their pals, ""海へ行こう！”（let's go to the ocean!) but ONLY ONCE THEY WERE ALREADY THERE, then they might specifically suggest going to the 海岸 - as opposed to other things to do by the sea. Weird!
accross the sea - foreign countries, basically.
in the kaiiiigun, you can sail the seven seeeeas, in the kaiiiigun, you can put yourself at eeeeease...
the most general, broad, useful word for regret
to insult (to be insulted : 侮辱を受ける　（ぶじょくをうける）)

the social, everyday world - more poetic than 世界。 Used in dramatic declarations like, ""I'm sick of this fuckin' world!"" ""I don't care about this life!"" ""Poor Kurt Cobain, he was just too sensitive for this cruel world!"" Also, usually implies JUST Japanese society.
in the middle of doing XXX.

someone who is faithful in doing his/her duties. Also means like a movie which is faithful to the book, or a translation which is faithful to the original. Or even a forgery which copies the original dollar bill completely well.
admonishing negative advice: ""Don't open that door!"" ""Don't swim naked!""
a patient. Easy to remember because in California the かんじゃ can legally get ガンジャ.
friendship, OR membership in a group (i.e. working for the same company).
to make up　with XXX
weakling, gayrod
a cavity (literally, 'bug tooth,' because parents would tell their kids, 'If you get a cavity, bugs will crawl in the hole and nest and lay eggs.')
parasite (literally, 'close living insect')
din, discord
to belong to such-and-such a department. ""Hi! I'm Ross Henderson, from Marketing!""
to be physically attached or part of a set. The bolts and nuts that come with an ikea furniture thing.
retire, retired person (Fucked Roots - retirement is cowardly? I see! I'll work for the Emperor until my arms fall off!)
a robber - not like a mugger but like a break-into-your-house-when-you're-not-home guy
someone who is shit-faced drunk (泥酔する：  to BE shit-faced)
the reason you hate doing your mom's laundry.
a peach-shaped ass. This is considered the ideal feminine shape by Japanese people, since they don't have a lot to work with. Your mom's got a momoshiri, too- it's covered with fuzz.
the physical process of printing, as in printing press - not to be confused with 出版 (しゅっぱん＝publishing), which is an entire industry.
Edo (a period of Japan's history). 江戸時代  (えどじだい) = Edo Period.
family register - what Japanese use instead of a social security number for the purpose of verifying their identity.
place, like a parking lot. Also space, as in, your moms can't ride in my new van because there's not enough space.
strong point, as opposed to weak point. Can be used about people (his 長所 is his courage, her 長所 is her brain) or machines ('The strong point of this PC is its long battery-life')
weak point, flaw
to bear a burden, a responsibility.
to fire (although mostly people just say, クビになった！ (literally: My throat was cut!))
A somewhat formal term for one's own wife (FR： female cluster? What's that about!??)
heating : central heating, electric heater, an air-conditioner set to ""heat,"" etc.
animal fur - on a living animal OR on a fur coat
tail someone like a detective
reform (the welfare system, the campaign-contributions laws, etc.)
to not take an opponent seriously because you assume they are soft.
PREFIX: you can put it before any noun, with no particles in between, for example:
rash, impulsive, unpremeditated
find (your car keys that you thought you'd lost)ー BOOBOO: you don't use 見つける about things you're discovering for the first time. That's 発見 (はっけん）!
tolerant, broad-minded, gracious, lenient
environment (like English, this is not limited to nature. A bad kid can be a ""product of his environment."")
means border or boundary of property (80% the same usage as さかい　（境） , but a bit more formal).
figure of speech, expression
the current place. (this one is used on the 'YOU ARE HERE' part of maps)
the present time - but also can mean ""the present situation"" or ""the staus quo.""
kind, emphasis on action: specifically doing favors for people.
father ー which is weeeird, since ""CHICHI"" is slang for breasts.
all living relatives even ones you have not met
siblings (not just brothers)
conquest, control, subjugation. But it can also mean, 'Recover from or overcome an obstacle.'
the state of affairs, the condition, the context: どういう状況でその言葉を使う？ (どういう　じょうきょう　で　その　ことぼあ　を　つかう？ = In what situation do you use that word?)
economic slump or recession; Republican administration

unless you're talking about a literal foot-race, 競争 does not mean a game. It refers to competing within a framework (usually business or academic). The best score on the test, the salesman who sold the most this month.
a broke motherfucker (can be used as a noun or adjective)
savings.(BOOBOO: used only about money in the bank - not stocks or real estate investments)(
quality of merchandise　(品質のいい/品質の悪い）

natural quality. In contrast to 性格（せいかく）, 性質 applies to rocks and things as well as people and animals. Also it refers to the inner nature of people, rather than their social selves. So if you wanted to say that someone was very outgoing and loved sports and bars, you wouldn't use 性質. But if you wanted to say that someone was very stoic or honest, you would.

BOOBOO: Most books say this means 'detective' but really it means private detective, not police. (police detective is 刑事　－けいじ）. There's a huge P.I. industry here - they have advertisements in all the magazines and even posters on walls on the street!
all the members of the group
damage - to your body, but also to your property. Often used when you lose money on a deal. Usually implies that the damage was not intentionally caused.
a physical , as opposed to governmental law, as in 'law of gravity' or 'murphy's law'
predict,forecast
to do something consistently all the way till it is done. (一貫性　（いっかんせい）= consistency)
a custom or practice (of a person or a culture)
an achievement or good deed
ranking of the results of a competition （i,e, the results of a test, a race, or when a hostess bar posts the framed pictures of their #1,2,and 3 earners outside the club on the marquee!)
(adjective): enterprising, (adverb) :positively, aggressively. Someone who is really active and getting shit done and having opinions and stuff.
area, like square meters.
fucknuts, douchebags.
a noble, that is to say, someone from a noble family.
inheritance (but, sadly, you can't say 'isan suru' to mean 'inherit.'- you have to say 遺産を相続する　（いさん　を　　そうぞく　する））. . . .fuck!
a gene (heredity is 遺伝　（いでん))
a win or lose situation. Fighting over a girl/boy. Not neccesairly the final, decisive battle, the Superbowl. . The game/battle is won or lost on account of ..XXX. .
an antenna or feeler, like an insect or lobster's got
the texture of something (i.e. how it feels when rubbed on your skin)

a physical sensation of touch, as in ""I've lost all feeling in my left ball."" Also can be used as ""impression"", as in, ""What kind of feeling did you get from the interview? Do you think it went well?""
a business, a line of work: (the camera business, the pimp game, the clock business, etc.)
your sister　(when your brother when he runs out of meth money, he turns into a `売春男') !!
one after the other, in rapid succession
procedure (usually involving forms in triplicate and irritating bitchy secretaries)
the situation is grave, serious, and worsening. Used with something that was kind of ill to begin with, and if you don't act now it'll get much worse.

condition something is in. Can be used with a living thing or object. Always used only with いい or 悪い. Unlike the related term 調子（ちょうし）,具合 emphasizes the condition IN THE SHORT TERM - the condition at that particular time of day.
cheerful, energetic. Doesn't matter if it's totally forced.
PREFIX meaning ""former XXX' (ex-boyfriend, former prime minister, etc.)
right at your feet, right in front of you. often seen on 'watch your step!' signs)
perfect, as in 'the perfect crime' or 'perfectly safe.' Also, perfect as in, 'My new project is perfectly complete, now the finishing touches are over.'
completion (noun) - usually said of a painting, construction of a building, or other physically creative project.

complete or total. ""Don't stand up until the bus comes to a complete stop."" Perfect victory: 100 to nothing. Not used about people, except for this idiom: 完全な人いない (nobody's perfect) 。 Also used when creating things. To perfect a new invention or complete a new artwork.
western part of Japan (Osaka, Kobe, Kyoto)
to vote (also, it can mean election, as in ""Did he win the vote?"")
A goal - usually not something you do all at once. Usually related to self-improvement in some way: ""My goal is to learn French in 2 years.""
""marked"", as in 'Obey the rules which have been posted on the wall', or 'Follow the marked trail', 'Follow the target kitty which has been tagged with a blue collar.'
Japanese-style booze, or what we in the west call Sake. (BOOBOO: In fact, to Japanese, any booze is Sake)
a person who likes to drink booze
merit or worth - not used about money (it's worth it for the view! The good part of Dancehall is the bass!)
price of commodities in general. (Tokyo prices are high! The bananna market took a hit as prices continued to fall!) An economist might use this word.
ｏｎｅ’ｓ　ｍｏｒａｌ　ｖａｌｕｅｓ - used with specific things, like drinking, smoking, gambling.
demand - more strident than  the related word 求める　（もとめる）
demand in the economic sense - supply and demand
coward - the nuance is someone who becomes paralyzed when the shit goes down. Someone who is too frightened to react.

a group of banks, corporations, and underworld guys, where everyone is on each other's board of directors - like capitalist feudal states. These are the fuckers who bankrolled and encouraged Japan's role in the second world war. FDR specifically told MacArthur to break them up, but Mac didn't.Companies like Mitsui bank and Mitsubishi, Nissan, etc. have profited handsomely off of slave labor and Hirohito's war, and they continue to be the bedrock of society.

usually seen on the ""ingredients"" label on food packaging. But also used about source material for a report: field notes, raw data. The implication is that, unlike 素材, the source material is not totally raw, it's partially assembled --for instance, if you get silk, that's 素材, but when the silk is woven into a fabric, that is 材料, and then the fabric is an ingredient of a handbag.
close the store for the day (although people usually say 終わる instead!)

to agree with a statement - not just agree but also support, as in ""Many people support this new law."" ""Most of the committe members support the chairman's fuckin' proposal."" ( in this case, it is usually used about a great number of people, not just one individual)
to make change - i.e. ""Do you have change for a dollar?""

literally, ""rule,"" but closer to the English word for ""discipline.""Rules typically say ""don't do this or that,"" but 規律 give long lists of things you HAVE TO do, in the order you have to do them. Like if you're at military school, you have to get up at 5:30, have your bed made by 5:35, shine your shoes by 5:40, and report to the mess hall.

：A very archaic word for ｔｅｓｔｉｃｌｅｓ！　Although you'll never use this,
the roots are so awesome, I had to include it' the balls are apparently the 'spiritual habitat' of men.
honor : usually used by lower person to higher person. ""It's an honor to meet you, sir!"" ""I'm honored to have a chance to work with you, ma'am.""
a SIMPLE Japanese word (note the 単 kanji) : 犬 is a tango, as is a hiragana word like いや. But compound words or long-ass words are not tango.
the simple kind of X as opposed to the complicated kind (not rude). Also, simple-minded, mouth-breathing person (pretty rude).
delete (as in, delete a file, but also to eliminate or censor something)
passive person who always is like, 'I dunno, what do YOU wanna do?' and never starts any new projects.
to delete (computer term) delete a file or folder. Also to eliminate, as in process of elimation. Elimination. Whatever, it's only a dictoinry. Dictionary. FUCK! More coffee.
cheating, having an affair　(can be used even if you're not married)
someone who is oblivious to social rules, not a rebel way, more like in a spaz way. - ういてるひと doesn't have any friends and sort of floats around on the periphery of society.
the reception desk in an office.
means 'appropriate' - but more relaxed than related words like 適当 (てきとう)　and 正しい (ただしい). . .妥当 is more like ""adequate.""
the act of teaching： pedagogy, that's what I'm fucking talking about.
adopt a policy or resolution
cutting down a tree. Logging.

jukugo.m: each xxx in its own way.
jukugo.d: each thing in its own way. 各々考え方が違います。 (everyone thinks in their own way/ everyone has their own opinion).
PREFIX- you can put 各　in front of a noun to make it mean ""each one, respectively""：each place, each thing, person.

love or relationships in general - that is to say, if there's an ad for fortune-telling that says, ""Test your luck in money! Love! and health!"" it'll be using 恋愛. If there's an article in a womens' magazine, ""How to get love in 10 steps!"" it'll be using 恋愛. But you wouldn't tell a hot guy "" I 恋愛 you very much!"" See?
to keep your cool. Often said as a command： おちつけ!!
corrupt in one's personal life - not usually political corruption. Drugs, lies, trife behavior.

(literally,'the fallen group.') this is - along with Ainu, Korean ex-slaves, the Eta-hin,and the handicapped, one of the main groups discriminated against in Japan. I won't go into the whole story here, but most Japanese will say, 'Don't say 部落民, it's 差別 (さべつ＝ discriminatory)'
fail an exam,or get held back a grade.
pass a test.(opposite： ふごうかく)
to inform, to let someone know. Like, ""Let me know if you're coming. Call me when you get there,"" kind of thing.
abbreviation or acronym, like CIA or SHIELD, NWA, or KRS ONE, BDP, CREAM, etc.
paved road - small or large
condition, as in, ""You gotta be Japanese to come in this club? Are you jokin'??""""

article 9 of the constitution, which states that Japan can't have an army. Right? WRONG. Japan CAN have an army - they just aren't allowed to invade, an inconvinient fact that both pacifists AND right-wingers seem to forget.
superior, excellent
to lead or conduct : A teacher leads the class on the field trip. The policewoman conducts traffic. The nuance is, 誘導 means literally going together with the people to the place.
transparent (like water or glass)(BOOBOO: not to be confused with 'invisible', which is 目で見えない　（めでみえない））
to permeate (like mud permeating a towel); to stealthily take over  (communism) ;　osmosis
vampire (literally, 'suck blood devil.')
a rank, grade, class.(usually used in the sense of social class)
quiet or tranquil place

intrusion or infestation or - sometimes - interstitial or even good old 'entry!' If you're talking about intrusive, anxious thoughts that make it impossible to enjoy a sunny day, or whether you're talking about a burglar intruding into your home, or an infestation of maggots in a wound, or even if you're planning a particular point for a moon landing, しんにゅう is your boy. Holla!
green tea (AKA the only time you'll ever use the on-yomi for 'green')

appropriate, as in an appropriate gift. However, 適当　also means irresponsible! Doing something without considering the consequences. 適当な人間だ！ “He's irresponsible. He'll say anything that pops into his head.”
house-cleaning. Not just sweeping, but vacuuming, straightening up, smacking the futon, etc.
empire - in the literal, non-judgemental sense of 'having an emperor' (England, China, ancient Inca). I don't think 帝国 carries the bad nuance of 'imperialism' (i.e. warlike or colonialist).
a leap. Usually figurative. Make a leap forward in technology. Not used as a verb.
to jump horizontally, as in the Olympic long jump.
construction work - buildings or roads, i.e. what guys do outside your window.

carpenter. How awesome is that!???! Seriously, I wouldn't even believe my friend when he told me,I was like, 'Cmon, grow up.' He was like, ""What is so funny about a daiku carpenter?"" I made him look it up in the dictionary and prove it.
fall colors; fall leaves
to handle a tool skillfully
photo (take photo:　写真を取る （しゃしんをとる））
extreme - Ｕsed about people, people who take things too far. (not tempratures or political ideologies)   A 2-foot-tall mohawk is 極端.
to get to the bottom of. To exactly assess or find the reason for something.
to take into account the special circumstances (i.e. before you punish him for vandalism, remember to take into account that his dad just died).
Usually refers to a religious ceremony. Or sometimes a secular one: a swearing-in of a new president, or even someone with O.C.D. who has to clap their hands 4 times whenever they touch a doorknob!
a game (of pool, tennis, etc.)
a test, like in school - kind of formal. (BOOBOO : normally people just say テスト)
weapon: has the nuance of sword or small gun.
political delegate or group represtntative
a generation  (as in, generation gap, the me generation, all that stuff)
SUFFIX、usually found on store signs, meaning 'rental': room for rent, parking space for rent, etc.(FP;note how the last ""shi"" is pronounced but not written. )
annoyance. Can be used as an adjective (迷惑なｘｘｘ） or as a verb (迷惑をかける＝to annoy).
injury.  I am GUESSING that the difference between 怪我 and its synonym  傷 (kizu),  is that kega emphasizes the severity while 傷emphasizes the appearance- spots, cuts, scabs, etc.
pirate (pirate DVDs go by the wonderful neologism of ""海賊版DVD"")

a region or district, a zone. (emphasizes a social community moreso than a geographical area) (i.e. you wouldn't use it for the tropics or the Arctic, but you'd use it for Chinatown ,the American South or Kanto/Kansai)
a territory or domain controlled by someone. Also used in neologisms like ""domain name!""
challenge (challenge yourself to do better, test your limits / challenge the system) be defiant or provocative. take the pepsi challenge!

jukugo.m: bonsai. Oh man, this entry was so not worth even making. Deeeyamn.

jukugo.d: A machine, particularly something with a motor in it which moves when activated. A computer is not a 機械 , but a robot arm is.
mood (bad mood: 不機嫌!)
a social crisis (oil crisis, global warming, etc.)
a chance, as in, ""I hope I will have a chance to go to Australia someday."" or ""This could be my only chance to see yo mama's huge collection of Rosie O'donnel pap-smears.""
occupation　－ a slightly formal word for job.
an organization or structure - usually social (like a union or mafia)
SUFFIX meaning 'ward'- for example,
to make a distinction - to tell one thing from another - 2 synonyms, for instance. or 2 similar-looking kanji
the government office for your ward- where you get your immigration paperwork and junk.
huge guy! Like a dinosaur or Gandam.
a giant, like Andre, but also a important person, as in, 'Microsoft is a giant in the software industry.'
Think you can figure this one out?
physical distance between two things: towns on a map, for instance, or the distance between an archer and a target - a much bigger distance than the related word 間隔.
cabinet Minister (Minister of Finance, Minister of Defense, Minister of Butts and Asses, etc.)
stress, stretched to the max ーcan be used both literally and figuratively.
an art show or art exhibition.
a formal way of asking your superior to view something. either 'ごらん ください' or 'ごらん に なる.'
a GIANT exposition. Not like, ""Cezanne's greatest fuckin' paintings all up in here festival"" but huger - like a World's Fair.
temporary, acting, provisional
it's a counter for animals, up to maybe the size of a deer. (BOOBOO: anything bigger than a deer is counted with 'とう.')
master craftsman, who teaches disciples and apprentices. If he's awesome but doesn't have apprentices, you don't use this one.
4 hours' time. As in, this bus ride takes 4 hours.
swap, exchange (Japanese/English language exchange, for instance)
to transfer buses/ trains.
What Japanese bathrooms never have.
shortcoming. Opposite of 長所（ちょうしょ）. Can be used about people (he drinks too much, she always lies) or machines (this PC is very slow and prone to crashing).
defective, defect
A kind of formal word for failure to attend, absence.
PREFIX: ""欧XXX"" means, ""European-style XXX.""
singer. Not like Joey Ramone, but like Celine Fuckin' Dion or Pavarotti or someone.
counter for flat objects (ichimai, nimai, sanmai, yonmai, etc.)
sensitive (in both the good and bad sense)
any failure! Flunking a test, your plan fails, no one comes to your party, your business goes bankrupt, your mom's chest waxing goes wrong and her pec-fro winds up as Beyonce's wig.
a total disaster.
accident - not like you spilled your Coke, but like a traffic accident or a dude getting smeared by a meteorite.
a slightly more emphatic version of ""Why?""
a breakdown or malfunction
Christian church
often, frequently
breeding. Unlike the related term 生殖 （せいしょく）、繁殖 refers to the entire process of finding a mate, not just the physical act of insemination: Breeding grounds. Mating season. Farmers breeding livestock.
A military-style massive, planned attack.
college major, field of study

Wonderful! Magnificent! This is usually used only by women, and it is used in reference to things made or done by a third party - you wouldn't say your friend's cooking was すてき, but you'd say a dress your friend wore was すてき.
One's own (as in, self-control, self-hate, self-help books, one's own discretion)
remodeling, renewal, or reorganization　of a physical thing ; re-modeling a house, tricking out a car, re-organizing the leadership of an organization.
improve a thing - your performance in Math class / the economy / the efficiency of the car

a record (like the minutes of a meeting or a log-file), but also a record like Guiness' Book. To break a record, like your Moms did at the Special Olympics, is 記録を破る　（きろくをやぶる）.
a memorial, an anniversary of something good , like marriage or a band's anniversary gig. Or something you give your friend to remember you by.

jukugo.d: personal needs (love, shelter, food).
the world, the physical planet Earth.
soccer??? No, wait, badminton.
eyeball (doctor's word- most people just say 目玉　（めだま）)
majestic , slow and dignified but scary - like a bunch of gangsters slowly walking down the street while the Peter Gunn theme plays. Or a parade float of your mom's neck-beard.
to overwhelm (圧倒的な (あっとうてきな )= overpowering)
physical pressure (usually seen on tanks of high-pressure gas)
the type of guard who protects innocent people: the security guy at the bank, the Secret Service.

heavy
industry, like 'the steel or construction industry.'
the A-bomb　(a contraction of 原子爆弾 (げんしばくだん))
light socket, where you plug shit in.

to be rebellious, defiant. To start a revolt. Unlike the related words 抵抗　（ていこう）　and 対抗　（たいこう）、　反抗 has the nuance of 'rebel for the fuck of it,' like a teenager would.
a reaction - despite the 反 kanji, 反応 is not neccesairly a bad reaction. As a noun, it's value-free. (careful! This is pronounced NOU, not OU)
reply. In Japan, even if you respond to your friend's email 5 minutes after you got it, you have to start all mails with ""Sorry my reply is so slow."" (お返事が遅くてゴメン！）　（おへんじ　が　おそくて　ゴメン）
A noun meaning, ""the act of going downhill."" Unhelpfully, this is not used as a verb. What the hell, man?
""the act of going uphill."" Same deal.
mask. (literally, ""temporary face"")
all the Japanese letterforms which are not Kanji - hiragana,  katakana, okurigana, furigana, oshirigana, nurenuregana, bakana, and whatever they think up next!
vending machine, usually shortened to. . . 自販機(じはんき)
fidelity to your lover. (used as noun or na-adjective)

lung --PSYCHE!  Unlike all other organs, lung does NOT use the '臓' suffix - it is just 肺。(BOOBOO)
counter for ""years old"" that a person is.
eradicate (a pest or disease) 'The new task force will eradicate drugs once and for all!'
an authority one has based on power alone (parents, cops, etc.) rather than on rights (authority based on rights is　権利（けんり））
a visual hallucination
oh HELLS yeah. It feels good.(although this isn't dirty by itself, it is the #1 actual word yelled in pornos.)
(literally, 'different feeling') crazy - this is one of the biggest cusses in the whole language-a garunteed fight-starter. This is instructive in several ways.

to belatedly realize something - d'oh!

one of them 400-footer godzilla monsters with the zipper on the back.
you know that WASP song, 'fuck like a beast?'
The most common, general word for gratitude.
to be moved by something (a song, a movie, a speech, a pretty poem about asndfisdnf)

a fairly formal way to say, ""Aaaah shiit!!"" Really really regrettable, deplorable. Only use this about some big thing - North Koreans kidnapping people, or that time you accidentally wiped your nose with the Emperor's tie.
in the same way. For example, ""In the same way caffeine perks up the mind, your dad's naked pictures perk up the body.""
anyone at work who out-ranks you
a master of ceremonies of a TV show or event. It's not used for 'sucker MCs' which is a darn shame.
a vacation, or just travel in general.
a traditional Japanese inn that costs like 300 bones a night.
showy and flashy, gaudy

A faction within a political party or corporation. Like every country has factions, but 派閥 has the nuance of 'We all claim to be loyal to the organization but behind closed doors we are plotting to hijack it with our own agenda.' Nobody would say publicly, ""I'm in this 派閥！”
juice, clout, pull, suction
CULTURAL CODE WORD in full effect. Meaning, it's such a uniquely Japanese concept there is no ready English equivalent.
the exterior, the surface  - unlike 面 (men), 表面 is more technical - usually used by architects or craftspeople. Or, for instance, to describe a ""skin"" you'd put on a polygon 3d character.
to depend on- usually in a bad way, like ""America's dependency on foreign oil""

a request or commission. Not like 'Please pass the salt,' but like 'I'd like to hire you to make a custom suit' or to hire a lawyer or PR firm.  Any relationship where you'd use the phrase ""The client wants. . ... ""is 依頼。
a mystery bag, a grab-bag that stores use to get rid of old inventory.
trial or lawsuit - a court case, anyway!
prize - but not like on Wheel of Fortune or the lottery. Like if your kid cleans her room, you give her a cupcake. Or if your dog performs a trick, you give it a bone.

a waste of time or energy; a financial loss
masterless samurai or misfit nerd obsessed with same - note the left kanji means 'wavelike', and a ronin is a kind of drifter.

the fundamentals (how is it different from 基本？ Well, with 根本, the emphasis is: the fundamental, deep, organizing principles, not the most easy 'for dummies' bits). The essential and underlying - as opposed to on the surface and easily apparent) Also handy:こんぽんてきな (the adjective form)
roof . That's right, not root. Roof!
patience. You need 根気 to be able to 我慢 (がまん）。
guts　/balls (for instance, giving yourself cigarette burns to prove some kind of point about being a man)
it's not necessarily the case that xxx!
A somewhat literary word for one's hometown （BOOBOO: most people just say 実家　（じっか）, meaning ""parents' house"" instead).
influence (You don't say ""x influences Y,"" you have to say ""Y recieves X's influence."" (YYYはXXXの影響を受けた）
story of a building. いっかい、にかい、さんかい。。。
a step in a process. A measure, as in ""We're taking steps to reduce your mother's underarm emanations."" Also a palindrome of stairway!
2 meanings. 1= a disability, like a handicapped person . 2= an obstacle like some shit in the road.
safeguards or security, like at the airport. It also can refer to a deposit - a promise to pay money if you damage something.
beauty salon. Yes, hospital （びょういん） and beauty salon (びよういん） DO sound totally alike.This is one of the basic mindfucks that teachers like to spring on newbies, so act like you know.
anti-crime / crime-prevention (you tend to see this word on hidden cameras or locks a lot)
PREFIX meaning, xxx proof, or xxx resistant. (for instance, 防水のnippleclamps(ぼうすいの) water-proof nippleclamps. Handy!
at your convenience, xxx. （ i.e. with the new hack, we can break into their system at will). (since the Endangered Raver act has been repealed, we can harpoon 'em whenever we feel like it).
'capital city of XXX' in the sense of 'Hollywood is the film capital' or 'Paris is the art capital' or 'San Francisco is the bear capital.'
some / a certain part of (some complaints / part of the community / some lesbian separatists / some parts of the body / part of the crops)(
dissect - both literally and figuratively: to psychoanalyze someone, or understand their motivations.
SUFFIX. For example, ２倍 means, double the amount. 3倍 means triple the amount, etc.
magnificent, epic

a manner of dress- not just a uniform. If you tell your daughter she's not leaving the house 'dressed like that', that's 服装. Or if someone shows up to your party dressed way too formally, that's also a 服装 problem.
せお＊う： lit： to carry on one's back. Figuratively, to assume the burden of.
uniform (nurse, student, policeman, fireman, stewardess, army guy. . .)
compulsory, forced. ""Do it, slave!""
consumer electronics- anything from stereos to calculators to ipods. Radio Shack, Bic P Kan, and Yodobashi Camera are 電気製品 stores.
This is a SUFFIX which has two meanings, to wit:
manufacturing, production
to confess- both to a crime and to having a huge crush on me.
an advertisement - although nowadays people use the Japlish word シーエム (CM, short for 'commercial.')
a report. 報告 has more of a nuance of a scientific, governmental, or corporate report than the related term 情報 (news report)
creative (BOOBOO: don't confuse it with the OTHER そうぞう：想像, which means 'imagine.') (I know, it's pernicious!)
last year. PSYCHE。 you didn't think it would be that logical? last year is 去年：きょねん.
a shitter
screen - both movie screen and computer/tv screen
the ground/floor (applies both inside and outside)
to save face (opposite: 面目を失う　（めんぼくをうしなう））

to reduce, cut back on something. (business word)

literally this kanji means 'foundation stone,' but unless you're a student of architectural history, you'll be using the metaphorical meaning instead: 基礎 means 'the fundamentals' (of a language,of a philosophy, or a martial art, etc.)
mountain-climbing. （verb form:　やまのぼる）
a geographical district or zone - emphaizes a physical location: the tropics, the steppes. ちたい is much bigger and broader than 地域.

sponsor a medium party or company event (like 催す（もよおす） but the emphasis is on 'sponsor' (i.e. provide money in exchange for publicity), where as もよおす has more to do with actually doing the work - arranging the chairs and snacks and sweeping the floor, and so on).
host a big event like the Olympics
a collapse- said of a building, but also (figuratively) like 'The collapse of communism.'
a vengeful ghost - unlike 悪霊（あくりょう） and 妖怪 （ようかい）, 幽霊 were once human and driven by revenge. 幽霊 are more popular in horror movies (like The Ring), whereas 妖怪 are more traditional.
peninsula (lit: 'half-an-island'!)
sticky, disgusting soybean remnants that Japanese like to inquire if you can tolerate them.
Means 'You're smart!' . . . or maybe it means 'Well, you're a sly one, aren't you?' (if they say the ね at the end, chances are it's the latter)
a figurative prayer or wish, made to pass a test or to not go to jail ,etc.
No exact English equivalent. がんばる combines two English expressions: 1) do your best! 2) good luck! You tell your friends 頑張れ！ before a big test or job interview.

an item (on the agenda), a clause, a subject heading
order of people in a line (take a number!) - order of bands on a live show.
fine, fair, no problems, smoothly. Usually used like this : ""Hi! How's business these days?"" ""Oh, 順調、 I can't complain!""

western style (suits, furniture, food, buildings, etc.)

obligation or honor debt. Like, you went to my band's show now I have to go to your band's show even though you guys are really terrible.

a serious, formal bow - the real bow, not the head-nod.
not quite an argument, but definitely a spirited loud discussion.

the situation. Usually used in medicine or business: The patient's situation is grave. We'll wait and see if the market situation improves. 様子を見ましょう！ The other main way it's used is: 様子がおかしい！　Which means, 'Something funny is going on here!' or 'There's something funny about that person.' 'You mean the homeless with a stuffed duck on his head?' 'Yes.'
All different kinds of xxx. Very similar to 色々（いろいろ）, but 様々 means more like ""all the kinds of"" rather than ""many kinds of.""
attatch (a file to your email) (read the attached instructions)
to laugh explosively- to suddenly and convulsively guffaw
to see a friend off - like as far as the train station.

these are the hiragana letters dangling from the end of kanji, like the ""べる"" in 食べる or the ""り"" in 送り仮名。 okurigana are useful because they cue you to pronounce the kanji using KUN yomi, rather than ON.
something that is relevant; something that seems related: two murders in the same week with both bodies' heads missing.
一巻、二巻、三巻; いっかん、にかん、さんかん、 : first , second, third volumes in a series of books
whirlwind or tornado
out of range / out of your jurisdiction
the English -speakng world; countries that speak English (no stars. . .This isn't used very often, but it gives you a good idea of what this kanji means)
Take pretty much any noun you can think of, and aｄd ""券"" to the end, and you have invented a coupon for that noun.
student (more formal, ususally used with the name of the institution: Harvard弟子、 Waseda 弟子）
the first (impression, priority, episode/ game of the season) the primary thing.
the second step (in a plan for world domination)
literally, to boil some water. Figuratively; to seethe with anger or get too excited
expenses, for a road-trip or a night out, misc. things you have to buy.

To study.  Used about learning a whole subject, such as Irish History or Thermodynamics. (BOOBOO: 勉強 takes months or years, as opposed to 学ぶ　（まなぶ）　which means to learn one thing, and can take a second.)
：someone who is rugged, thuggy, street-looking.
blush (other than this, you don't really need the on-yomi)
ruins of old buildings.
lover - (BOOBOO: 恋人 is usually the good kind, where no one's cheating. The bad one is 愛人）
SUFFIX meaning ""Boss of XXX.""
height (BOOBOO; only about human bodies- not about buildings or, well, anything else)
extension or prolonging, in time. Also means,to extend a linear thing by building it longer. A bit more official than the related term 伸ばす　(のばす).
notebook. Not the big school kind. The tiny kind Japanese girls are always sitting alone in cafes penciling in their social engagements in.

Medical checkup. Also, investigation, inspection, review: (fiancial audit, smog check, check the condition of goods that roll off the assemby line, etc). Has the nuance of a test where something passes or fails.
to give thorough consideration to the topic. To investigate something thoroughly. Often said by politicians who don't want to give a real answer.
frugal, saving money, getting bargains. (BOOBOO - 倹約 is used in a good way. If you want to say someone is cheap, say 'kechi!')
the wooden-sword-fighting martial art
an experience
rich person AKA your mom's bail bondsman.
a debt - What the Yakuza comes to break your knees if you don't pay.
to enter data, or to register  for something - (usually means filling out a form)
chain. Usually used figuratively: chain store and chain reaction. Cycle of child-abuse. Food chain.
Ginza , a ritzy neighborhood in tokyo
YYY, which is a subsidiary of XXX. (Fanta is a subsidiary of Coke)
plan - not like, 'I'm planning on going to Lake Tahoe this weekend,"" but like a big-time business plan or world-domination scheme.
food. Can be used of the ingredients OR the finished, cooked product.
two meanings - 1) cooked rice, 2) a meal
as a prefix, it means the main (office, manager, road) rather than a branch one
disposable XXX, throwaway things.
room/time/money to spare. Like, don't sweat it.
on the way to XXX (I stopped and got some chips and a sody).
means ""warehouse,"" but also ""storage"" (as in the English phrase, ""It's in storage."") 倉庫 is a stand-alone building - a warehouse or shack in back.
seminal or original - a new idea that was the basis for a trend. None of the bands you like are dokusouteki. They're all ripping off the dokusouteki artists. You poser
troublesome, worrying. Hard to deal with! A hard-to-fix appliance. A stubborn, persnicketty person.
the world, as in ""biggest in the world!"" ""fastest in the world!""
Suffix meaning, 'the world of XXX', as in
those clothes look good on you.
a big meeting or assembly of people - can be used for business meeting as well as fun meeting like a concert.
wages -  a bit more useful than the related word 給与. For instance, 'payday' is 給料日 (きゅうりょうび)、 not 給与日.
to supply (supply and demand / supply the troops with guns / supply your kid with a school lunches / the feed chute supplies grain to the conveyor belt at the cereal factory)

エッフェル塔= Eiffel tower.
to board a plane, train, big boat. Usually seen on signs 'Board over here, fool.' .
to come equipped with XXX (built-in camera, etc.)
backtalk, sass
""That's too bad."" - kind of informal ; say this when someone didn't enjoy a movie they went to, or couldn't come to your party because they got the flu.
as a precaution, in case something goes wrong.
an order, a command.

cool-headed, calm person - someone who doesn't panic when the shit goes down.
unreasonable, irrational, unjust
the last stop of the train.
one after the other, in rapid succession
gradually, by degrees
ｐｏｓｔｕｒｅ　－　 posture, both literal and figurative. Unlike the related word 態度（たいど） one's 姿勢 is always intentional - something one consciously adopts.
data, primary sources, the material you use to write a report or a historical novel
perform music or a play
old-school porn drawings of samurai getting it on. Remember the one broad with the oral sex octopus? Major shunga.
in fact. (as in, 'You think you're Samoan, but in fact, you're adopted.')
一冊（いっさつ）＝１ book, 二冊　（にさつ)＝two books, etc.
prejudice or bias　－not always racial
an essay, like a senior thesis.
theory, as in science or ""theory vs. practice""
one's personal ethics or principles
Usually used like　今、誰かつきあってる？　('Are you seeing anyone now?') Ｓｔａｌｉｎと付き合ってる. ('I'm dating Stalin.')
clean up the room or desk. Not just sweep the floor but like straighten up all the papers, put the pens in a row, etc.
to encourage someone
affiliated - i.e. a research institute which is affiliated or attached to a certain university. Or, included, as in 'use the gloves included with the hair-bleach kit.'
to be away from home; to be absent (留守番電話　（るすばんでんわ)＝ leave a message at the tone)
a group of people united for a purpose (Citizens Environmental Lawsuit Group),
a little fried dumpling, usually served 3 to a shish kebab.
a tickeｔ (only used for a concert or a train, or bus)
hamburgers?? Hot dogs??? Dumbass.
to introduce - not a person but a new concept or thing. ""Billy Fuckpants introduced tea to Europe from China.""

SUFFIX meaning, ""temple of xxx."" BOOBOO :  Most Buddhist temples have the 寺 kanji at the end of their name, and in that case it is pronounced ""JI"". But if you are talking in general about temples, you say ""tera"". got it?
sometimes, as in 'sometimes this is written in hiragana.'
SUFFIX . . . actually, it's one of TWO Japanese suffixes that both mean 'plural.' 等 is kind of a more macho suffix than 達(たち）, and it's ONLY used in the following words : 彼等： かれら(them)
the formal Japanese you use when you are addressing your superiors.
to look up to or respect someone. (BOOBOO: it's not ok to tell someone directly, 'I 尊敬 you very much!' - you'd say it about a third party)
a trade school, like for electricians or anime voice-over actors.
the opposite effect from what you'd intended.
someone is a specialist for XXX. In other words, they have a fetish for xxxx. Like デブ専 is a ""fat person specialist""
a natural history museum or aerospace museum. (fine-art museums are 美術館　（びじゅつかん））
to restrain, to restrict, tie up in red tape.
any public speech or talk given to a general audience. Authors doing a reading, dudes addressing a club, the graduation speaker at your graduation, are all doing 講演.

a genre of really un-hip music Japanese grandparents and hicks listen to - it's been called ""the country western music of Japan"", but it's much more. When you listen to Enka, or sing it in a karaoke bar, you can cry and express emotion.

the event is full, there's no seats left
full moon. Also, when you moon someone with your ass, that is also a mangetsu.

not what it sounds like! Houman means zatfig, voluptuous. This has two meanings： a) a borderline sexual-harassment word used generally about the big titty women. b) a a relatively polite way to describe a chubby woman. Anyway, ABU!
departure of train, bus, plane.
a thing made in XXX, a person from XXX。
drawer or chest of drawers.

jukugo.d: ：stiff or formal, tight-assed.
PREFIX。 it means 'canned.' 缶ビール is a can of beer.
to be agitated or unsettled, to be jolted
to take care of someone sick or old or retarded. What your mom did.
atrocious! Heinous! Some Rape of Nanking kind of shit.
horrible luck, an atrocity.
gray matter, brains.- the ""miso"" part is written in hiragana, but it comes from the word 味噌, or 'soup'!!!

The dictionary says ""separation, "" as in separation of church and state, or ""the river separates the two countries."" Politically it means to segregate people, like in the American South, or what Japan does to Burakumin.
suspect in crime; foreigner.
PREFIX meaning 'quasi-XXX'
doctor
a more formal word for doctor -(you wouldn't say ""I need to see the 医師!"" - you'd say, ""I need to see the 医者（いしゃ）！”）
a SUFFIX meaning, 'XXX branch of medicine -' in other words, 'XXXology'.
medical treatment- the kind one gets in a hospital (x-rays, MRI, surgery, etc.)
your immediate family - parents, grandparents, siblings.
two meanings: 1) ethnic group, 2) folk (as in folk customs, folk music, etc)
climate - not like the weather we're having today, but the general climate of a region - temperate, tropical, etc.
a sign that something will start soon: (Those clouds on the horizon are a sign a taiphoon is coming)
a flyer, or a sign on the wall - usually advertising an event.
to agree in theory　(business - speak). Stronger than 承る（うけたまわる）.
to pretend you don't know what I am talking about, to feign innocence
rude, without manners.
'iron man,' not as in the Sabbath song, but as in a bad mother fucker. (this is the kanji from Iron Chef)
a train-spotter, a train-obsessed nerd.
a notion, an idea. (BOOBOO: Not like 'I got an idea! Let's start a food CO-OP!' But idea like, 'He has no concept of personal hygine.' 'That's a very stereotypical idea!')
to advise or counsel someone.
the authority or right to do something
power (over other people)(as in boss, parent, governor, pope, etc.)
certainty. This is never used as a verb. You'd never say 確実する。
This word used only during war (excuse me, during KINETIC OPERATIONS), and it means territory or positions held by a military force.
THIS is the ring you wear!

basically the only time you will see this is as a counter for houses or shops:
いっけん、にけん、さんけん、 etc.: For example:彼はレストランを三軒もつ。 (""He owns 3 restaurants"")
this word combines both synonyms for 'soft.' So you know it means really feeble, weak, nerdy.
flexible, like a Crazy Straw / elastic
Basically means the same thing as 載せる、 but 掲載 is a little more formal: to be reported.
an army - but not necessarily the whole army. It could just be some troops.
The Land Army (as opposed to navy or airforce)

jukugo.m: reveal the extent of one's power
