jukugo.r: うんがいい　/　うんがわる

jukugo.d: luxurious, in a good way
Chinese (often seen on the signs of Chinese restaurants)
a somewhat medical-sounding word for sleep (BOOBOO: you would never say, ""よく睡眠した?"" -You gotta say, ""よくねた?"")

PREFIX (sometimes SUFFIX!) meaning excessive - sometimes as in an overdose of drugs, an excess of personnel, but usually an excess of an attitude or behavior. This prefix is the only time you'll ever see the 剰　kanji.
race of people. (BOOBOO - 人種 is not ethnic group like Albanians, it means race like honkeys.)
laborer. proletarian
emergency. This is the word on all the emergency exits and emergency firehoses. But you'd never say ""I'm having an 非常！”
PREFIX meaning 'without xxx' Usually words use the 不 or 無　 prefixes, but occasionally you'll see a 非-word, like 非常識　（ひじょうしき）　(no common sense) 非対称的　（ひたいしょうてき）(asymmetrical).

jukugo.m: Person ahead of you at school
jukugo.d: Usually translated as ""person ahead of you in school．""　(opp.後輩 (こうはい））. But the 先輩・後輩 system of unchanging, rigid heirarchy is in full effect all throughout Japanese society, from the punk scene to corporations and everywhere in between. People still call each other 先輩 40 years after they graduate.

jukugo.m: someone younger than you in school

jukugo.d: a somewhat literary word for pessimistic
tragedy (opp: comedy!)
terrible, harrowing, tragic. Usually used not about a single person’s misfortune but like the tragic cost of war, the terrible catastrophe that befell the small town in Godzilla’s path, etc.
yo mama so fat /
the dook (doctor word, although it's sure to get a chuckle if you use it)

to eliminate (another doctor word, which could mean poo OR pee, which is what is so excellent about it) (especially if you speak almost no Japanese but know really advanced medical terms for turd dropping)
a loose tongue : either a mean gossip, or someone who can't keep a damn secret even if they try.
someone with experience - usually a negative experience. In which case the closest English word would be 'survivor' (of abuse, discrimination ,etc.)
a traditional Japanese monster from folk tales. They have physical forms, but don't necessairly attack people. More like the European ""fairy"" than ""monster.
a somewhat formal word for friend, used mostly by older people.
to see through someone's pretension or their deception.
idiot( usually KANA, so one star : *)
useless, academic word for rare animals or plants.

right wing :pro- LDP, pro-emperor, anti-union, pro-yakuza, anti-article-９. anti-the-whole -macarthur-fuckin-wrote-it-anyway constitution. Not necessarily anti - western. After all, the USA is the main ally in the fight against the Red Menace. It's easy for Americans to say, 'communism is dead, get over it,' but we're not the ones living next door to fuckin' Kim Jong Un.
left wing： pro-union, pro-article ９,anti-national-anthem, anti -LDP
shared / communal / jointly owned things.
the owner of something. (しょゆうする； to own)
useful or beneficial, (a policy beneficial to the State /it was a useful experience (a learning experience))
SUFFIX meaning, the mathematical difference between ２ things, as in 時差　（じさ： the time difference between two places).
preserve - usually used with traditional culture or morals more than environmental causes. You'll often see this: 保存員会　（ほぞんいんかい） preservation committee.
katakana - the letterforms which are used to write foreign words and indicate emphasis. Oddly, the word ""katakana"" is written in Kanji. Kind of defeats the purpose?
to compensate someone for a favor they have done you, to aid someone with money or material things. When high schoolers date salarimen for money, it's enjo kousai.(援助交際）

support - usually used with support groups like ""adult children of alcoholics"" or ""a heartwarming show of support for a city which has had a natural disaster"". It's not limited to victims but it has that sort of nuance to it.
to cheer for or root for someone at a game.
one single hair from a human head (as opposed to pubes), (i.e. there's a hair on the floor/ cloggin' the damn drain?)
color, in the abstract sense : color palette, color wheel, color blindness.
""She made a sour face"" = sour顔をした。 ""He made a mad face""= mad顔をした。
a casual word for surrender: to give up mid-game. A politician concedes defeat. To say uncle.

jukugo.m: go to a temple to pray

a tragedy (BOOBOO: not as in a sad play, but as in someone's sister died while giving birth. A dramatic tragedy is 悲劇　（ひげき） )

the act of brushing the teeth
('Brush your teeth' = 歯を磨きます!）
slang term for a lady into BL comics.

Literally it means to zoom in on or magnify. Figuratively it means to escalate (a conflict) or scale-up (a buildup of some sort)
a kind of formal word for attendance (at an event)
to interrupt. Often heard in the phrase: おじゃまします!('May I come in?') Used with co-workers or friends who are busy. Not used when you go to a store or someone's house.
I am The Devil, do you understand?!? (used only for the Christian devil, not native Japanese demons,which are 鬼。)
witchcraft - Applies to anything - flying, shooting lightning, turning dudes into trout.
a captivating, charming, glamorous person (not used about movies or artworks)
a lure or fascination - in the old sense of fascination (i.e. sirens luring sailors to their doom.)
hideous - more literary and more extreme than the related word 醜い (みにくい).

not just a coward ,but someone who does treacherous, trifling bullshit because they're a coward - like if they fight you they know they can't win fairly so they'll knee your groin, they're a 卑怯なmotherfucker.
to put yourself down (BOOBOO: only used when talking to others - mumbling ""I suck!"" to yourself doesn't count for some reason)

generally, for the most part, in most cases

density or concentration

""at the time of XXX, do YYY"" ..  . As in, 'As long as you're going to the kitchen, get me some pretzels, you crazy broad.'
to guess or speculate about the meaning of someone's behavior or words. 推察 is only used when you have no real proof.
cultivation, development or exploitation of a country or resource.

abolish (slavery, alcohol, heroin)

incident, as in crime or accident. Something you gotta fill out a report if you were a witness.

not 'sexy', more like 'nasty.'
sorry (usually KANA, but it's worth learning to see the roots of the expression: 'Honorably exempt me (from your wrath!)')

literary symbol ; ""In the novel, the trees symbolize life."" 'The color red in the painting symbolizes communism.' (しょうちょうする=to symbolize something)

abstract (thought) or figurative (meaning)
image - usually it refers to an image on the computer screen which does NOT move (JPGs, basically).

behavior, conduct. Can be used in a good or bad way.

Expectations. For example,
今回は負けたけど、次に期待しよう！　（こんかいはまけたけど、つぎにきたいしよう！） We lost this time, but I expect we'll win next time!
Or, I expect that my students will give at least 33% effort.
to make someone wait. The person at a cash register will generally say 'Taihenおまたせしました!' if you have to wait over 3 seconds.

employee, personnel

sex organs (no stars- people usually say 性器　せいき!)

to push someone down. Actually this isn't so useful but I read it in a gay porno and so .

convert to new ideology, do an about-face. This is important because most of the freaky looking kids you see on the street will all become housewives and salarimen the exact second they turn ２3. - making TENKOU what we call a ""cultural code word.""
when a salariman gets transferred to another office, that's tenkin.
a legend - King Arthur or Lord of the Rings or whatever.
SUFFIX- put it at the end of a word to mean 'spirit,' as in 'fighting spirit,' 'winning spirit,' 'patriotic spirit,' and so on. In that sense, it's not like a real ghost or religious thing.
oil paint, like what Rembrandt and Picasso use.

shopping district. Not quite a mall, but a street with a tin roof, and all the shops are decorated similarly.Like all the stores on that street formed a kind of merchants' association and tried to give their street some atmosphere.

continent (ie. what your Mom is not)
a large number of people - not in the sense of 'It's crowded today' but like 'There were crowds waiting to greet the Ambassador' - the crowd is united in its purpose.

passionate! Although pretty far from how we'd use that word in english: the Japanese version means ""dedicated , hardworking, diligent."" 熱心な学生 (a passionate student)  . . perhaps a better translation is simply 'enthusiastic.'
passion - usually used about sports or performances: They praised the actor's passionate performance. She's passionate about her hobby.
the tropics, tropical zone
to counter (used with two roughly equal things that oppose each other) (i.e. a counter-reaction, counter-demonstration, compete in the marketplace, counter-culture, antagonist, counter-balance)
bathrub. I mean tub. A bathtub.

hunger (no stars!)

temporary, provisional management of a problem, until a lasting solution can be found : usually medical (i.e. stabalize the patient), but sometimes used about jury-rigging a machine. Take care of the radiation leak. Manage the PR crisis.

commonplace, ordinary, mediocre (i.e. rapping about rims)

architecture. So help me God I'll never spell that word right.

a petty bureaucrat ass-grower like at the DMV. These are almost as unpopular in Japan as they are in the West, so maybe don't ask someone ""Are you a 役人?"" to their face.
an institution, some facilities. (a mental hospital / sports stadium / orphanage / water filtration plant)
a murderER is a 殺人犯　(さつじんはん)
a comparatively polite way to say ""crotch""
contradiction / hypocrisy　 (interesting: the kanji literally mean 'spear plus shield'! Picture a guy claiming his shield is for self-defense, even as he holds a bloody spear in his other hand) . . ..
circulation - whether blood, air, whatever.
to bite someone's style, to impersonate
discreet, careful
imprudent, indiscreet
xxx - prefecture (Japan has prefectures instead of counties)
to really bust ass and do one's utmost.
obedient, gentle (kind of usually used in a sexist way to compliment a lady. I have a hat with sunao written on the front which always is good for nervous laughter.)
to leave something alone. (similar to 怠る (neglect), but 放置 is value-neutral. 放置する just means ""leave it as it is."")
reproduction, as in 'reproductive organs,' or 'the reproductive process'
separately, as in ""separate checks""　at a restaraunt
parallel
intense, furious : close to 激しい　（はげしい）： a punch, a violent speech. Emphasizes the extent of emotion invested in it.
severe, violent, terrible, fierce -
fervent, passionate enthusiasm.
soybeans in the pod, usually slightly steamed and salted.
heartbeat (although most people just say ドキドキ, the sound of a beating heart)

Destruction. Ususaly used about bombs, or 'President Bush destroyed the economy,'. . . pretty much the same circumstances you'd use the English word. (BOOBOO: you can't use する with this one, for some reason. It's one of those nouns you can't verb)
radio wave/ reception - why do you need this one? Here's why: 電波が悪い (でんぱがわるい　＝ the reception is bad here - I can't hear you on my keitai!)

jukugo.postParticle: のある　or のない

jukugo.d: reservation, appointment
Preface or introduction.

you know that word that all the rappers call each other? In Japanese, that's やろう。 Like the American equivalent, やろう can be a term of camaraderie or a big insult, depending on how well you know the rapper.
literally 'spearhead'; figuratively, the brunt.
the office. Although, they say that some Yakuza groups also call themselves 'jimusho' as in, 'If you don't pay, they won't be happy down at the office.'

jukugo.m: alienation (usually it means alienation from society or the world at large - more of a withdrawl or angsty thing)

jukugo.d: to become estranged from, alienated from (usually used about a specific person or people: ex-husband, family, group of friends, etc.)
arrange things, like arranging papers alphabetically, or arranging books by topic.
personal character (kind of a formal, news-paperish word. Usually we'd say 性格　（せいかく）　for personality, or 性質（せいしつ） for someone's essential nature)
General, informal word for any kind of sickness or flu.
SUFFIX meaning, ""xxx-disease""

literally, to be tone-deaf, unable to carry a tune. But you can also say, 方向音痴, which means 'to have no sense of direction,to get lost a  lot.' One more idiom: 運動音痴: (undou onchi) means terrible at sports.
grumble or mutter a complaint over and over - to bitch, whine, grouse, sing the blues. (as opposed to 文句 (もんく) which means make a loud and articulate complaint)
SUFFIX meaning XXX-disease. Only used in the proper names of specific diseases, in contrast to 病気（びょうき）, which means sick in general.
symptom of a disease
a very disapproving way of saying ""but still"". As in, ""He don't even have money for rent but still he just got a ＄２00 Bathing Ape shoe."": 家賃の金もないの癖に二万円bape靴を買っちゃった！
to take shelter , to evacuate
a senior bureaucrat - not the kind at the DMV, but the high powered kind that get like millions in bribes, kickbacks, and revolving-door funds.
soy sauce! (usually KANA, so I'm just giving it *)
accidentally, coincidence
spouse (you only need this if you are getting married to a Japanese and want a 'spouse visa.')
outdoor hot springs baths - AKA the best shit ever.

an evil spirit; a spirit who puts curses on people, or brings misfortune to entire towns, or possesses innocent fools. Unlike 幽霊, they don't attack you directly, and unlike 妖怪 don't have a physical form
inspiration.
us (said by men)
electricity. Also, instead of saying 'lamp,' most people will merely say, 'Turn on the denki, would you?' (BOOBOO)
one's turf, or territory (kind of a street term)

necessities:  both on everyday occasions and on adventures. Like if you're leaving the house you need your keitai and your keys! But also if you're going to the moon you need your ray gun and your moon bikini.

this is an excellent phrase. It means, to do things halfway. Whether it's doing a half-ass job at your work, or taking a girl out on a date . . . .to burger king, or cleaning your room but only to the extent that your mom's turds are in a bag and not on the floor. - that's all CHUUTOHANPA.
No sooner had I done XXX, when YYY happened. (where the た is the end of a past-tense verb: tabeta, nonda, hashitta, etc.)
courageous (people usually just say 勇気（ゆうき））
a warning or admonition. Not like ""Be careful!"" but more like ""You better not!""
pharmacy (BOOBOO: 薬局 sells perscription drugs. . .the regular kind of Wallgreen's -ass drug store is 薬屋 (くすりや)）
to physically restrain (handcuffs / strait-jacket) to legally restrict (carbon emissions / immigration quotas / freedom of speech)

Mostly this is used as a SUFFIX which turns a noun into an adjective. Like how politics becomes 'political,' or how education becomes 'educational.' or economics becomes 'economical.' In Japanese, 政治　becomes　政治的な.
the basics (the emphasis is: the minimum knowledge)

rational OR reasonable (i.e. get up at a reasonable hour or a reasonable compromise - like 'logical,' but used even if there is not a mathematical proof involved. Also has the nuance of efficient - the boss says to the worker 仕事合理的に進めなさい！　（しごと　ごうりてき　に　すすめ　なさい！）, meaning, 'Stop wasting our time and money! Work in a more efficient, rational way.'
an average (adjective form: 平均的な）
uniform, even (both figurative and literal: level playing field, uniform lighting, equal opportunity)
to steal in a violent, mugging kind of way.
plagiarism - biting of one's style by a sucker MC.
an alliance, league, union (usually used with military alliances: NATO, UN Security Treaty nations, the Warsaw Pact alliance, etc.)

a federation : unlike the related terms 連合 (れんごう）　and 同盟　（どうめい）, 連盟 is made of individual people, not federated nations or gangs.  れんめい is more like volunteers. Baseball clubs, Chess associations, the League of Women Voters, are 連盟。
to get exciting, to liven up.
a bulging pudenda. Not like an average camel-toe. More like a set of labia that is thrusting out of a pair of tight pants like a she-boner.

to supervise, or watch over a project. Also means, to guard bad people - guards at a prison, a teacher who watches students at test time to keep them from cheating. (BOOBOO: don't mix this with 警備 (けいび), which is someone who is guarding or protecting good people or things).
one's seal or stamp with one's name on it, which the Japanese use instead of signatures.
a field guide; a book where each page has one picture and a description of a thing. (birds, gandams, monsters, doinks, whatever).
to have a 'discriminating eye' for art. To appreciate art or music on some deep, expert level.
expert opinion. Like an American Idol judge or art critic or some guy in court who says that tobacco does/does not cause cancer.
general public - in the political sense. ""This politician appeals to the general public."" ""Public sentiment is against the tax hike.""
An honor or prestige that comes in the form of a seal of approval or bonus points from an authority figure. Usually used like this : 名誉なこと。 名誉を受けた。
the base, basis, or foundation
PREFIX, meaning fiercely XXX (i.e.　猛反対：fiercely against)
Mostly used BY older men, and ABOUT a certain kind of person;  Nasty, dirty, obscene. Not always used in a bad way.
gross, obscene. Always bad. Used about a behavior , not the person doing it.
an expression which means, ""Monkey see, monkey do!""
hunting for XXX (including humans)
As opposed to 狂ってる (born crazy), 発狂 is someone who is normally sane but had a breakdown from stress, or a sudden flip-out.
unique, or a quality particular to some thing or person
autonomous - a colony becomes an independent country; a business start-up that is not under the umbrella of an established conglomerate, etc.
to obtain. Very similar to 獲る　（える） but 獲得 has the connotation of ""obtain with great effort"", or ""FINALLY obtain."" 獲る is more like, obtain something easy or small.
bitch-slap　someone right in the XXX.
Business Japanese: An upper person rejects,dismisses, or  overrules a proposal made by an underling.
joint - like an elbow or knee joint , in a skeleton.
an inhibitor, or suppressor. Basically it's the Noun form of 抑える.
welcome (a warm - , a hearty - a lukewarm - )

someone who is too formal, pompous, high-falutin'.  You're like ""Hi, dude!"" and they're like ""Salutations, my good man! Verily the sun doth shine like the Emperor's benign gaze upon this blessed land!""
to be flabbergasted - in a good way OR a bad way.
data.The information that goes IN reports.
a lame gift - by law no matter what you give someone, you have to apologize to them for not giving a better gift. You say,粗品ですが、どうぞ。
a small or wack pud. That is to say, an unsatisfactory penis.
poor quality, shabby

an investigation. Emphasizes that there are no correct answers, and implies that the investigators are talking to someone, asking questions directly. (usually used about polls, surveys, and detectives questioning suspects and/or witnesses)

a real-estate or architectural term. . .specifically, it's a measure of how big a room is. For instance, a 4畳 room is big enough for 4 tatami mats.  I know it seems like, ""Why should I learn this?"" but if you ever plan to live here. . .
an assistant, a helper
one's own personal ancestors. Ancestor worship.
includes the meaning of 先祖, but it's more broad. 祖先 can also refer to ancestors dating back to monkeys, fish, germs, etc. ""The two words/phyla of fish/languages share a common ancestor.""
one's field of view; like insects can see 360 degrees and etc.
a holiday - whether you get the day off from work or not
a more polite term for god or gods
shinto, the state religion of Japan

occult, mystical, supernatural-ish. Not like poltergeists or Alistair Crowley, but like a painting with a spooky vibe or a secluded nature spot where it's easy to imagine forest spirits jumpin' out on you.
in thanks for. As in, ""In thanks for the sweater, I bought him a moray eel.""

literally 'politeness money.' - sometimes the phrase ""key money"" is also used - as if that explains anything. This is the legalized bribe you pay for the privilege of paying rent on a new apartment.
violent - ""He's a violent guy"" or ""She's a violent /crazy driver"" - violent weather, (can be noun OR adjective OR verb!)
totally nude - as in, your dad with your high school coach.
half nude, as in your dad with your Moms.

Plural - in English ! . . .The Japanese language doesn't really have a word for 'plural,' but Japanese use 複数形 to describe English plurals. So you'll need this word to correct your Japanese friends' frequent grammar boners.
""Look at the deers!""
""Deer doesn't have 複数形、, Yoshio。 3 deer is still 'deer'.""
""チクショウ！”
multiple (causes of the disease / reasons for the decision / effects of the medicine)
(usually said by macho guy/ country child) I'm hungry!
when a samurai commits suicide by slicing his guts out. (切腹 is kind of formal - in casual conversation, you'd say 腹きり  (はらきり） instead。)
review what you've learned - like vocabulary or even kanji.
the Shibuya neighborhood of Tokyo (lit. 'bitter valley'、which kind of makes sense when you go there and smell it.)
greed : can be used about people OR greedy institutions- you greedy Americans, greedy-ass Wall Street.
the hooker biz, (BOOBOO: as opposed to 水商売 (みずしょうばい）, which encompasses the hostess-biz, hooker-biz and general nightlife-biz.)
'to put it in slang terms,XXX' . 'commonly,'as in 'your mom, commonly known as 'Big Bertha,'...)
old-school folk customs or music.
boogers: (literally ""nose poop""!!)
SUFFIX meaning 'the dialect from the city of XXX.'

to be vigilant, to take precautions.
To be on high alert - police or security. Describes a tense but temporary situation.

jukugo.m: jump up from out of nowhere
jukugo.d: to jump out in front of you suddenly. Normally you'll see this on road signs, ""Drive slow! Children might dash out!"" Unlike the related words 跳躍 and 踊る, 飛び出す emphasizes jumping FROM a place. Jumping FROM the side of the road, or FROM the shadows.
Achilles heel, soft underbelly. A built-in weakness that - while not correctable - is not a deal-breaker either.
development or exploitation of a country or resource
Along with Sonkeigo, Kenjougo is half of Japanese formal speech: When talking to your superiors, you use kenjougo to refer to your own humble actions.
to have your name entered in the koseki (family register)
a hostess (literally, ""cabaret lady"")
shamelessly slacking off or avoiding one's responsibility.
abnormal (as in 'abnormal psychology')
suicide-bomb. (like PLO, not like Kamikaze) Suicide-bomb terrorism is 自爆テロ　（じばくてろ）
re-opening, resuming
day after next? NO. Of course not. Day after next is しあさって!
a branch of a chain store such as Macy's or a Best Buy. Regular stores are xxx店 (てん) or xxx屋さん (やさん)。
a polite way to say, ""Don't worry about it.""
structure of a physical thing: cell structure, house structure,structure of a society.
purchasing (usually used in a business context)

jukugo.m: Oh, No! Please God help meeeeee. . . .:(
jukugo.d: the year Black Sabbath released their first album.
the fifth day of the month. Also a homonym for 'when,' so that Abbot and Costello routine practically writes itself.

SUFFIX meaning ""language of xxx-country""
(for example, フランス語、ドイツ語）
a tale- often used in the title of a book or movie. As in 'the tale of genji' 'tale of two cities.'

a misunderstanding - like the related term 誤解 , but 勘違い is a little smaller. If I'm reading and confuse one kanji with a similar looking kanji, that's 勘違い. But if I see my fiancee with her cousin from out of town, and assume she's having an affair and punch the guy, that's 誤解

jukugo.m: a somewhat formal word for difference

jukugo.d: . . .in the sense of 'historically great', 'history-making', 'most famous', rather than the sense of 'nice' or 'wonderful.'  (Recall Louis Farrakhan's wonderful non-apology for calling Hitler a 'wickedly great man':  ""Hey, White people!  You're the ones who forced me to learn your language, and now I speak it better than you! You can't even be bothered to open a dictionary and learn your own language, so who are you to judge me?""
self-defense - usually used in 自衛隊 (Japan's army, the Self-Defence Forces)
an instant, the blink of an eye.
where your mom gets her makeup from.
to do a 'sympathy visit' to someone who is sick, usually in the hospital.
someone from the neighborhood - a homey.

２ meanings.
1： cooking , as in, ""My hobby is cooking. I'm cooking right now, I can't talk.""
it's too late now, after all this time. Too much water under the bridge.
rigid - but not like a boner. Like a rigid class system resistant to change. Like rigor mortis. Other meaning: to sit bolt upright, soldiers rigidly standing at attention.
identity, as in ID card or unidentified headless corpse.
the contents of (a box, bag)
one's social status： bum, clerk, socialite, ne'er-do-well, etc
launch (a rocket)
to be up a creek, in a predicament, painted into a corner, fucked.

the others, as well as, furthermore, etc.
(often seen on charts: 45% Republican, 45% Democrat, その他 10%)
other people, people around you (emphasis is slightly negative: they're not in your group, so who cares about them?)
to put something - a plan or rule - into effect
all the more. As in, 'He ignores me and it just makes me love him all the more.'
SUFFIX  meaning, 'layer of xxx.' As in,
stratum of society - broke, blue-collar, middle-class, rich, oligarch
follow after someone all stalker-style.
to deport your Moms because she got naked on top of Tokyo Tower yelling 'Fuck Yamagichi-gumi!' through a bullhorn.
administration or management- you often see this on warning signs: ""Don't walk on the grass - sincerely, the management"", or on Windows ""コンプター管理” (computer management)
teacher - more fomal than　先生。
open for business (a sign you'll see on every store window)
SUFFIX meaning, the science of XXX. basically it means '-ology.'
""miscellaneous knowledge"" - the best section to find cheap, weird books at BOOK OFF.
a feeling or sense (touch / taste / smell / hearing, etc.)

the Liberal Democratic Party - the MacArthur and CIA-backed party which has remained almost constantly in control of Japan since the war, by using their secret stash of funds that Tojo stole from Asia. A lot of post-war LDP bigshots were war criminals. Take that, post-Nazi Germany!
the Communist Party. Of course, they're not real communists, any more than the LDP are liberals. I have no idea what the fuck these guys believe in.
another fine example of Japanese-style sarcasm： あまとう (literally 'sweet party') means someone who loves eating candy.  Actually, you can use the 党 for many jokes this way.
any prize which is NOT cold cash money
compensation money. Reparations. Also used in lawsuits.
everyday life - you know, on the quotidian tip.
one time around (the lake, the trail , etc.)
sculpture- but only the kind that is carved all Michelangelo's David style. The Rodin-style sculptures that are cast in bronze are OBJETs (that's right, they use a French word.)
drink too much. But really you can put ""SUGI"" after pretty much anything.
smooth, as in trouble-free and effortless.
entertainment like movies, comic books, Disneyland. . .
refugee; someone who is on the run

c.m: look at for a long time while lost in thought

jukugo.d: 1) (literally) a view from a high place (unlike related terms 景色　or 風景, 眺望 emphasizes the viewers' location, rather than the thing being looked at) ,

sudden AND unrelated to whatever came before it. Similar to 急に　 and 突然, but it emphasizes a random change, emphasizes that there is no cause-and-effect relationship. In other words, 唐突　is not just a sudden guy jumping out from behind a bush or a sudden thunderstorm. 唐突 is more like someone apropos of nothing changing the topic of conversation or getting mad for no apparent reason.
renounce, resign, ""I don't sell that shit no more, dude.""
like saying XXX san. You can use it about any little boys, but once they become high-school age, you generally only use it about your friends.
one's wife and children. The word for 'husband and children?'
an argument or controversy
a second-job. moonlighting.
to use something both as A and B.
a very general term for any kind of hurtful speech - from sarcasm or snarky comments, mean-spirited arguments, to outright belligerence.
modest - this is a word you use about others. ""She's got a very modest attitude.""
To downplay your own skills in front of others. You don't ever say ""I 謙遜-ed."" or ""He 謙遜-ed."" or ""She's really 謙遜-ish.""
any kind of building - western OR japanese.
to outlive others, to survive a fucked event
birthday
the birth of (figurative) (i.e. Miles Davis' ""birth of the cool"" album)
bank balance. You don't need to know this.
wiretap, bug
domestic violence, or some other bitterly bad but small-scale situation.
a doctor word for skin. most people just say '肌' (はだ）
to find a job (finally!)
to dis someone so casually that it adds to the dis. To win a game too easily, to reject a complaint, to just look at someone like 'Who are you and why are you breathing my air?'

period of time, usually several months. Or years. Precise, socially constructed time, not seasons or shit. 期間 is more like summer vacation. You are forbidden to enter Japan for a period of five years.
period of time - refers to a natural or social phenomenon : rainy season, the time that you can see fall leaves, the humid time of year.
ginormous, gigantic, fucking huge - almost always used about disasters. ""The gigantic earthquake killed 1,000 dudes.""
forgive, tolerate, stand by and let a motherfucker get away with.
already, as mentioned before
elegant, graceful, refined
to make a sweeping generalization. (usually used in the negative: 一概には言えない (I don't want to generalize, but. . . ) )
dimwitted, insensitive, thick-headed, sarcasm-proof

jukugo.m: opposite of xxx, or reacting against xxx
jukugo.d: this is a prefix, meaning ""opposite of""- you can put it in front of any word, the way you'd use ""Bizarrrro""
previously, earlier, in the past
a raid. Like an assault done by a team of people, not just one mean guy. Usually used about the SWAT team raiding a house. But a gang can raid another gang.
pilgrimage (in Japan, this means traveling a mountain road and visiting one temple after another, rather than going to one central holy shrine like Jerusalem or Mecca)
natural disaster - earthquake, fire, flood, your mother's flattus, etc.
a slightly more newspaper-ish word for a harmful blaze.

this means disaster - not in the sense of earthquakes or tsunami. Disaster in the sense of 'How was your trip to Tahiti?' 'Oh my god, it was a total disaster!!! First we missed the plane, then I got an infection, then on top of all that our hotel was run by zombies!'
a misunderstanding- often used about situations (a la TV sitcoms) or when you misread someone's feelings.
a typo
loneliness, solitude
parenthesis, or anything shaped like a parenthesis
it's xxx's fault that . . .
camouflage (including, of course, animals!)
someone who is accommodating of your needs.

getting financing or funding or a business loan (usually in return for taking the banker and his friends from the Ministry of Finance out for some hostess action and $3,000 sake). (and possibly 'accidentally' losing a golf game or two)
to quarantine people - or 隔離背策：(かくりせさく)　an official policy to keep people in concentration camps, like USA did to Japanese-Americans during the war, or like Israel is doing in Palestine.
PREFIX:every other (week, month, year, etc.)
a small physical distance or gap - a literal space between two things: between two close-together buildings, say, or between the train and the platform.
literally, 'No problem.' But, don't believe a Japanese if they say this. A salariman can get drunk, stumble into the street, get his legs cut off by a bus, and still claim to be 'daijoubu.'
polite way to begin a letter: ""Dear Sir""
beautiful - (now you know why it is a 'na-adjective'　despite ending in い: it was actually a jukugo in the past!)
